Award.AwardTitle: Modeling in Primary Grades (MPG): Science Learning through Content Rich Inquiry

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This exploratory project examines how teachers of second grade students scaffold the development of student conceptual models and their understanding of the nature of scientific models and modeling processes in physical science conceptual areas associated with the particulate nature of matter. Teachers receive professional development around ways in which they can facilitate productive disciplinary discussions with young children that result in students coming to understand core ideas in the Next Generation Science Standards. The project focuses on the topics of matter and sound based on the FOSS units "Solids and Liquids" and "Water," and the STC unit "Sound". It builds on an earlier project on life science for kindergarten teachers and students to expand the research communities understanding of how young children learn in science. Researchers from Purdue University are working with public schools in Lafayette that have high Hispanic populations and low SES, as well as a private school system with a more affluent population.

This project employs a mixed methodological research design that incorporates rich qualitative data collection and analysis combined with a quasi-experimental design that examines student learning across a treatment and comparison group with the same curricular materials but with differing support for teachers to engage students in disciplinary productive discussions about the science phenomena that they are studying. Research questions are designed to elicit descriptions of the differing aspects of learning that are evidenced by students together with rich descriptions of the teaching strategies that are associated with the classroom environments. Because this is an exploratory study, no causal comparisons between teacher practices and student outcomes are drawn, but the project provides the underpinnings that will support future research that would take a more rigorous approach. The project further develops the methodology of examining disciplinary rich description of student models to advance the understanding of how content and reasoning interact with young children.

Recent research in cognition has demonstrated that young children reason in a more sophisticated manner than previously understood. The Next Generation Science Standards has a strong focus on student reasoning practices, and the development of student explanations of science phenomenon requires that students have the opportunity to experience classrooms in which discussions of scientific ideas are scaffolded. Teachers need examples of how to interact with young children and of how to interpret what students say in ways that move the understanding of scientific concepts forward. This foundational research provides descriptive exemplars that can be shared in both the research literature and in practitioner publications as examples of what cognitively rich pedagogy can achieve.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.

The Modeling in Primary Grades (MPG) project (Award # 1222853) examined second grade students’ learning about the nature of matter in the context of content-rich, model-based inquiry instruction. The goal of instruction was to help students learn to use simple particle models to explain states of matter (solid, liquid, and gas), phase changes (e.g., melting, freezing), and the behavior of particles in a medium when sound travels through it. Historically, educators have considered such concepts too difficult for primary grade students to learn and particle models are seldom introduced until the upper elementary or middle school years. The project employed a design-based research (DBR) approach to iteratively design, evaluate, and redesign model-based inquiry activities that supported students’ construction and application of simple particle models for a wide array of material phenomena. To help students think about and use particle models, we collaborated with teachers to co-design modeling lessons for students. These modelling lessons were designed to complement widely-used inquiry activities from the FOSS science curriculum that was introduced to public schools across our state through a prior state-supported initiative. Over a three-year period, longitudinal data on student learning were gathered and analyzed from three separate cohorts of second grade public school classrooms in the Midwest.

The MPG curriculum had five related conceptual foci: 1. Meta-Modeling: Understanding the nature and use of models in science. 2. Materiality: Distinguishing exemplars of matter (solids, liquids, and gases) from non-matter (e.g., ideas, shadows) based on the properties of matter. 3. States of Matter: Identifying states of matter and explaining the macroscopic properties of matter in different states in terms of the arrangement and movement of tiny invisible constituent particles. 4. Phase Changes: Explaining macroscopic changes in matter during phase transitions (melting, freezing, evaporation, and condensation) in terms of changes in the arrangement and movement of tiny invisible constituent particles when heat is added or decreased. 5. Sound: Explaining the movement of particles in a medium as sound is propagated.

Key Project Findings. In each year of implementation, we found that over 75% of students who engaged in MPG model-based inquiry lessons learned to use simple particle models to describe and explain a variety of material phenomena such as differences in the appearance and behavior of solids, liquids, and gases and what happens during phase transitions. However, less than 30% of MPG students could successfully apply particle models to explain how sound travelled in a medium such as air or water. Figure 1 illustrates these patterns of findings with data from Year 2. Year 2 MPG students showed statistically significant gains in mean scores for each of the conceptual foci assessed, although the gains for Sound were much smaller. In contrast to the MPG students, the comparison (COMP) students (who learned the same topics as MPG students through FOSS inquiry activities without the MPG modeling components), showed a statistically significant gain in mean scores for Materiality but did not show gains in the other conceptual foci.

Variations in how MPG teachers organized and managed classroom science talk was related to the coherence in students’ models. Students with more opportunities to author their own models tended to use particle models more consistently across phenomena than students who were provided particle models by their teacher and then applied these models to new examples.

This pattern is illustrated in Figure 2 which shows longitudinal changes in Year 3 MPG students’ coherent use of particle models from pre to post interviews. Coherence scores for each conceptual area are represented in grey scale, with darker areas representing lower use of particle models and lighter areas representing higher and more coherent use of particle models. Students in Classes 1, 2, and 3 showed more coherent use of particle models than students in Class 4 on post interviews. Interaction analysis showed that teachers spent higher percentages of discourse time on model scaffolding discourse in Class 1 (22%), Class 2, (30%), and Class 3 (18%), than in Class 4 (9%). In parallel, students spent higher percentages of total discourse time on model construction discourse in Class 1 (29%), Class 2 (40%), and Class 3 (37%), than in Class 4 (7%).

The ability to model material phenomena in terms of the arrangement and movement of invisible constituent particles forms a foundation for much future science learning. Our findings provide support for the introduction of these ideas to students early in the science curriculum. Additionally, teacher professional development needs to focus more on supporting students’ authorship of models.

Broader Impacts. 

The MPG project has developed research-based modeling lessons that can be used to teach young students to use simple particle models to think about matter. Professional development materials for teacher are available to support implementation. The MPG project has developed measures of young students’ conceptual understanding that will support future research.
